Dispute_Type: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act matters
Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and reasonableness of H&C application denial
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence provided for lack of family support, fear for daughter's education, and threats from brother-in-law
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate compelling humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Credibility_Factor: Claims found not sufficiently supported by evidence
Legal_Rule: Officers have discretion in assessing H&C applications; procedural fairness applies
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for H&C decision; correctness for procedural fairness
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness in interview process
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of family support, educational concerns for child, safety threats from brother-in-law
Outcome_on_Merits: No merit found in H&C claims due to insufficient evidence
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: No procedural unfairness found in the process
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's personal statements regarding family, safety, and education
Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative law and immigration regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged both procedural fairness and substantive outcome
Legal_Rule_Source: IRPA, Canadian jurisprudence on procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Officer maintained decision was fair and reasonable
Remedy_Requested: Certification of a question of law and overturning of decision
Decision_Authority: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) officer
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and potential reinstatement of application
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 25(1) - Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations
Governing_Rule: Duty of procedural fairness and standard of reasonableness in administrative decisions
